claims.claim: Intratumoral mRNA vaccination triggers local innate sensing and type I interferon signaling.

evidence.quote: Type I interferon response score (normalized units) | 3.1 | 1.0
Blocking type I interferon signaling with anti-IFNAR1 eliminated the observed sensitization benefit.

claims.caveat: The reported effects are based on preclinical models and retrospective human data, not from a prospective randomized trial.

claims.claim: Interferon-associated antigen processing and presentation pathways increase after vaccination.

evidence.quote: Fraction of tumor proteins represented in immunopeptidome | 62.3% | 37.3%
Fraction of proteins represented in MHC-I peptidome | 40.6% | 20.6%

claims.caveat: The measurements of antigen presentation were from mouse models and may not fully represent human tumor biology.

claims.claim: The mRNA vaccination improves tumor visibility to T cells and increases immune infiltration.

evidence.quote: A broader peptide repertoire appears on MHC-I, improving tumor visibility to T cells.

claims.caveat: The observed increase in T-cell density is a valuable indicator, but does not solely prove a direct causal link to improved tumor destruction in humans.

claims.claim: Prior mRNA vaccination is associated with improved survival in patients receiving ICI treatment.

evidence.quote: Retrospective human survival comparison p-value | p=0.01 | N/A
Vaccinated subgroup had improved survival under ICI treatment

claims.caveat: The human analysis is retrospective and non-randomized; residual confounding is likely.
